citeinfo.title: Carriage Roads of Acadia National Park (CarriageRoads.gdb: CRd_LinearFeatures: CRd_LinesGPS2003)

descript.abstract: Contains lines representing Carriage Road centerlines on Mount Desert Island, mapped with GPS. All carriage roads that were open to public use in 2003 are included; this includes carriage roads both on public (Acadia National Park) and private (Rockefeller) lands in the Towns of Bar Harbor and Mount Desert, Maine.
descript.purpose: Intended for cartography & general planning use.
descript.supplinf:
Forty-five miles of rustic carriage roads, the gift of philanthropist John D. Rockefeller Jr. and family, weave around the mountains and valleys of Acadia National Park. Rockefeller, a skilled horseman, wanted to travel on motor-free byways via horse and carriage into the heart of Mount Desert Island. His construction efforts from 1913 to 1940 resulted in roads with sweeping vistas and close-up views of the landscape. His love of road building ensured a state-of-the-art system.
Acadiaâ€™s carriage roads are the best example of broken-stone roads--a type of road commonly used at the turn of the 20th century--in America today. They are true roads, approximately 16 feet wide, constructed with methods that required much hand labor.
Between 1992 and 1995, an extensive rehabilitation of the carriage roads was financed by federal construction funds along with matching private funds from Friends of Acadia, a nonprofit organization dedicated to protecting the outstanding natural beauty, ecological vitality, and cultural distinctiveness of Acadia National Park and surrounding communities. In 1995, Friends of Acadia established an endowment to help protect the carriage roads in perpetuity. Each year, the organization contributes more than $200,000 from this endowment to the park for carriage road maintenance.
The carriage roads in Acadia National Park are managed for non-motorized recreational use and cultural resource preservation. Bicycles are not permitted on the private (Rockefeller) carriage roads.

citeinfo.title: NPS Maintenance Division information

srcinfo.srccontr: hand-annotated map and printout of spreadsheet containing: FMSS Asset Number, asset Description/Name, line directions and proposed Federal Highways Route Numbers for the carriage roads

procstep.procdesc: Rover files (RAW GPS) downloaded from the Trimble GPS unit were differentially corrected using basefiles from University of Maine Forest Management base station (BASEFILES). The resulting corrected (.COR) files were exported daily as ESRI shapefiles

When fieldwork was complete, the various shapefiles were merged and basic edits were done to clean up the data and ensure that lines snapped together at intersections. Final edited shapefile was converted to ArcInfo coverage format using SHAPEARC. The IDENTITY function was used to split the carriage road arcs where hiking trails intersected. Basic attribute fields were added and populated (NAME, LEN_MI, BTWN_INT) once the coverage was clean. Coverage written to ACAD GIS SERVER.

Data layer converted to shapefile for editing. To facilitate use of this layer by park maintenance personnel, additional attributes were added to show the FMSS Asset Number, FMSS Asset Description, correct directionality of the lines, and tentative Federal Highways Route Number. Data loaded into a file geodatabase so routes could be created for FMSS Assets and FEHW Routes while still preserving the original feature data attributes.

attracc.attraccr: No quantitative accuracy tests were performed on the attributes. However the attributes have been "proofed by use" and corrected if any errors have been noticed. The field NAME was entered as a "best guess" by the data originator, and may not reflect names in use by park maintenance crews or in cultural landscape reports.

dataqual.logic: All lines meet at intersections, as they should. All dangles are legitimate trail ends. Lines have been visually checked against other existing GIS data. In the original coverage format, the data layer has been CLEANed with the LINE option. All dangles remaining represent the way the features exist on the ground. There are no duplicate features present.
dataqual.complete: All carriage roads open for public use in 2003 were mapped.

horizpa.horizpar: The data were collected with a Trimble ProXR GPS units, according to an accuracy standard of maintaining a maximum PDOP (Position Dilution of Precision) of 6, while tracking a minimum of 4 SV (satellite vehicles). These data were differentially corrected and have estimated accuracies in the X and Y direction of 0 to 5 meters, using the above standards while SA (selective availability) is set to zero. No tests were done to confirm this. In Trimble Pathfinder Office software, accuracy is not represented. Instead, precision is an estimation of the positional error (closeness to truth) available as feature attributes. To estimate precisions the software uses: receiver type (for noise), baseline length, Dilution of Precision, covariance and reference variance components. It is a repeatability measure not an accuracy measure. Horizontal Precision for line and area features looks at all the individual points that make up the line/area feature and a mean value is computed by the software. For Trimble data, two attributes in the database can give you more accuracy information for a particular line; MAX_PDOP tells you the maximum positional dilution of precision value while this line was being gps-mapped; AVE_HORZ_P is the average horizontal precision. Both of these values are calculated by Pathfinder Office software.

altsys.altenc: Explicit elevation coordinate included with horizontal coordinates

attrdomv.udom: Sequential unique whole numbers that are automatically generated.

attr.attrdef: the maximum PDOP (positional dilution of precision) value recorded while mapping this line segment. Automatically generated by Pathfinder Office software when exporting to GIS format.
date the line segment was mapped with GPS; automatically generated by Pathfinder Office software when exporting to GIS format.
the average horizontal precision value calculated for this line segment by Pathfinder Office software
general use name added by the originator in 2003
Length of the segment in miles, calculated from the SHAPE_Length field and rounded to 2 decimal places.
what carriage road intersection numbers is this segment between? order of the numbers implies to-from direction of asset
FMSS (NPS facility management computer system) asset number for this line segment. If value is 0, the segment is not tracked in FMSS.
Federal Highways' Route Number (tentative in 200807) for this line segment. If value is 0, the line segment is not tracked by Federal Highways.
Length of feature in internal units.

attrdomv.udom: Positive real numbers that are automatically generated.

attr.attrdef: FMSS (NPS facility management computer system) asset description for this line segment

attrdomv.udom: Unique name for each of 39 assets.

attr.attrdef: Length of feature in internal units.

attrdomv.udom: Positive real numbers that are automatically generated.

distinfo.distliab: The National Park Service shall not be held liable for improper or incorrect use of the data described and/or contained herein. These data and related graphics (i.e. GIF or JPG format files) are not legal documents and are not intended to be used as such. The information contained in these data is dynamic and may change over time. The data are not better than the original sources from which they were derived. It is the responsibility of the data user to use the data appropriately and consistent within the limitations of geospatial data in general and these data in particular. The related graphics are intended to aid the data user in acquiring relevant data; it is not appropriate to use the related graphics as data. The National Park Service gives no warranty, expressed or implied, as to the accuracy, reliability, or completeness of these data. It is strongly recommended that these data are directly acquired from an NPS server and not indirectly through other sources which may have changed the data in some way. Although these data have been processed successfully on computer systems at the National Park Service, no warranty expressed or implied is made regarding the utility of the data on other systems for general or scientific purposes, nor shall the act of distribution constitute any such warranty. This disclaimer applies both to individual use of the data and aggregate use with other data.
